CASE OF IMPERSONATION IN AMOY QUEE CAMP


    2. Dr Lau Teik Soon asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence if he will give details of the case concerning the person who impersonated a major and entered the 2nd Singapore Infantry Regiment, Amoy Quee Camp on May 9, 1985, and what measures are being taken to prevent an occurrence of such a serious breach of security in our Army camps.

     The Minister of State for Defence (BG Lee Hsien Loong) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    There are specific standing orders on security for military camps and installations. They are adequate.

    In the incident at 2SIR, a reservist Lance Corporal entered the camp by wearing a Major's uniform and claiming to be a

Column: 503

reservist officer. He has been prosecuted in civil court and fined $200 for impersonating a public servant.

    The reservist Lance Corporal was able to gain entry because the unit, believing him to be a bona fide senior SAF officer, did not check his identity. This contravenes the SAF's security standing orders which require that all SAF personnel, regardless of rank, produce their identification card for verification when seeking entry into a camp.

    All units have been reminded to comply strictly with existing standing orders.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): Sir, could the Minister of State inform the House whether there have been other such cases of impersonation and, if so, could he give details?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not have the figures with me. I do understand that this particular Lance Corporal in question had on previous occasions posed as an SAF officer and gained access to SAF camps.

NORMANTON PARK HOUSING ESTATE
(Resale policy)


    3. Mr Chiam See Tong: To ask the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence why purchasers of condominium units at Normanton Park, Ayer Rajah Road, after residing there for seven years, are not allowed to sell their units to non-Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) officers when no purchasers can be found among SAF officers at open market prices for those units.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Question No. 3, Sir, on behalf of Mr Chiam.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, Normanton Park Housing Estate was built in 1977 for sale to SAF officers with the following objectives:

    Firstly, to attract SAF officers to sign on as regulars.

    Secondly, to retain good officers who have decided to make a career of the SAF.

    Thirdly, to enable SAF officers to own flats at lower prices.

Column: 504



    There were also the additional benefits when SAF personnel live together, of helping to build up the sense of identity, allowing quick mobilization of manpower when needed, and providing for the general welfare of families, especially when the officers are away.

    These objectives of building Normanton Park still apply. To further them, the lease for each of the Normanton Park units contains a covenant that seven years after purchase, the owner may, with the prior written consent of the lessor, sell the property, but only to an approved buyer. In order to preserve the SAF character of Normanton Park as long as possible, the Armed Forces Council has decided that approved buyers should be serving SAF officers.

    Initial, and no doubt resale, prices of the flats have taken this restriction into account. The point-block units were sold in 1977 at prices ranging from $36,000 to $39,000. Over the last 10 months, 42 of these units have been resold by the original owners at prices ranging from $128,000 to $180,000. A further 11 units are in the process of sale. It would therefore appear that owners have been able to find buyers for Normanton Park flats at acceptable prices.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question for the Minister of State.

    As I understand him, when these flats were originally sold to these officers, they were told that the flats could only be sold again to MINDEF approved purchasers. Would the Minister of State appreciate that that is much wider than the restriction which I am told has now been brought in - that only SAF officers may buy them?

     Mr Speaker: What is your supplementary question, Mr Jeyaretnam?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Does the Ministry realize that they are changing their contract with the officers?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Sir, the Ministry does not change contracts which it has entered into. In clause 1(g) of the lease of the sale of the flats, there is a covenant. The covenant states:

    'Without prejudice to clause 1(e) [which is the bond period] not without the prior consent of the lessor in

Column: 505

writing to assign, demise, underlet, divest, part with, dispose of or otherwise deal with (except by will) the title, estate, interest, right to or in the flat, or share or part with the possession, occupation of the flat, or any part thereof.'

Therefore, the rules which MINDEF has made are perfectly within the meaning of this clause.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Does the Minister of State perhaps not realize the import of my question? Does he not realize that the clause in the covenant allows sale to anybody, not just SAF officers, provided the approval of MINDEF is obtained? And does he also not realize that that approval cannot be unreasonably withheld?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, clause 1(g) stands. I am not a lawyer. But I am advised by legal officers that what MINDEF has done is strictly according to the law.

SINGAPORE ARMED FORCES OFFICERS
(Preparation for a Political Career)


    4. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (a) whether it is the policy of the Government to prepare officers in the Armed Forces for a political career; and (b) how does the Government decide what political conferences army officers should be invited to attend and who should be selected.

     The First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government does not have a policy of preparing officers in the Armed Forces for political careers.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister state whether or not military officers have been selected to attend political conferences?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is no. Perhaps the hon. Member for Anson could enlighten me if he has got evidence of any such instances.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister say whether any officers attended the recent ASEAN Foreign Ministers' conference in Kuala Lumpur in July?

Column: 506



     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Sir, the answer is yes. I am surprised that that meeting is regarded as a political conference. In my view, a political conference is one where only politicians or parliamentarians attend. The meeting in question was a Foreign Ministers' meeting which included participation by officials. In that instance, an officer from the SAF was nominated to attend the conference.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister say whether only one officer was nominated or more than one officer was nominated?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Sir, only one SAF officer was nominated to participate in the conference as a member of the Singapore delegation.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister say what particular claim did this officer have to attend the Foreign Ministers' conference in Kuala Lumpur in July? And were the claims of any other officers considered?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, had the Member for Anson been honest with the members of the public in reproducing an article from The Star in the Hammer, he would have got the reason for the officer's attendance at the conference.

    The Hammer of August 1985 reproduced an article by courtesy of The Star in which only two paragraphs, out of three paragraphs, were printed. I thought the ending in the article was quite abrupt. So I asked for the original of the extract from The Star and, true enough, one paragraph was missing. Had this paragraph been published, I think he would have known the reason for the officer's attendance. I will read to the Member the missing paragraph. It says:

    'The Singapore Government makes it a practice to send its bright young citizens to conferences of this nature to acquaint themselves with international matters.'

    I think the Member has not been honest in his publication.

     An hon. Member: Hear, hear!

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister try and answer my question? The question is: what was the claim of this particular officer to attend the Foreign Minister's con-

ference? Have I made myself clear, Mr Minister?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the claim is as stated in the article: that he is a bright, young citizen in the public service of Singapore. And it is our policy to send our bright, young, civil servants to attend international conferences. It is to expose them and to acquaint them with international matters so that they will be better officers. Whether they are in the SAF or in the Administrative Service, it does not matter. SEPARATE HDB SHOP RENTALS FOR RESETTLEMENT CASES


    5. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for National Development whether he will consider having a separate system of Housing and Development Board shop rentals for resettled farmers and shopowners who, despite the discounts granted by the Board, are still finding it difficult to pay their present rentals based on the tender system, in order to alleviate their problem.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, at present, there is already a separate system of HDB shop rentals for resettled shopkeepers. While the rental for public applicants is based on tendered amounts, the resettlement rental is pegged at 90% of the rental paid by the lowest successful tenderer. Furthermore, under this system, resettled shopkeepers pay only 50% of the resettlement rental for the first year. Thereafter, the rental is increased by 10% each year until it reaches the full resettlement rental in the sixth year. Resettled shopkeepers thus enjoy rental concessions for a number of years. Resettled farmers are normally paid a cash grant of $26,000 as part of the resettlement compensation. If they opt for shop premises in lieu of the cash grant, they are also given similar rental concessions for a period of five years. Generally, these concessions work out to be more than the $26,000 cash grant.

    The concessions enjoyed by the resettled shopkeepers are best illustrated by an example. Assuming the market rentals for shops in a neighbourhood centre range from $2,000 per month to $3,000 per month, the rentals for shops reserved for resettlement cases in the same neighbourhood would be pegged at 90% of the lowest market rental of $2,000 per month. The resettlement rental is therefore $1,800 per month. In the first year, a resettled shopkeeper would only be paying a monthly rental based on 50% of the resettlement rental, ie $900 per month. This works out to be only 36% of the mid-point of the rental range for public applicants in the neighbourhood. Although the rental for the resettled shopkeepers would be gradually increased to the full resettlement

Column: 509

rental in the sixth year, the final rental of $1,800 per month still amounts to only 72% of the rental range for public applicants.

    The rental concessions enjoyed by a resettled shopkeeper are thus very substantial. Therefore, a resettled shopkeeper with normal business acumen will be able to conduct his business successfully. However, not everyone is endowed with business acumen, be he a resettled shopkeeper or a public applicant of HDB shops. No amount of rental concessions can help the person without the necessary business acumen to succeed in his business.

ANG MO KIO BRANCH LIBRARY
(Open on Sundays)


    8. Mr Lau Ping Sum asked the Minister for Community Development whether he will review the feasibility of opening the Ang Mo Kio Branch of the National Library on Sundays for the convenience of the residents.

     The Minister of State for Community Development (Mr Wong Kan Seng) (for the Minister for Community Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I reply on behalf of my Minister.

    This question of opening the libraries on Sundays has been raised in this House before. There are constraints on opening libraries on Sundays because of the shortage of qualified staff.

    The Ang Mo Kio branch library was opened only on the 17th August. Its present opening hours are from 10 am to 9 pm on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays. On Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, its opening hours are from 10 am to 6 pm. When the present staff vacancies are filled, the Ang Mo Kio branch library will open from Mondays to Saturdays from 10 am to 9 pm, which are the normal opening hours of our branch libraries.

    The existing opening hours of the National Library, which are from 8.30 am to 9 pm on weekdays, and its branches are already longer than those of libraries in the other countries with well developed library facilities. These hours should be adequate to meet the needs of our people. However, we will explore the feasibility of using part-time staff on Sundays or opening on Sundays but closing on a weekday.

     Mr Lim Boon Heng (Kebun Baru): Sir, will the Minister of State inform this House when the vacancies will be filled?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: I do not have an answer right now, but I think the recruitment by the Public Service Commission is under way.

     Mr Lim Boon Heng: Another supplementary question, Sir. Will the Minister of State expedite the process in view of the congestion at the Ang Mo Kio library?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Yes, we will try to do that.

IMPORT DUTY ON REFINED SUGAR
(Rationale)


    9. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Trade and Industry if he will explain the rationale for retaining the import duty on refined sugar after abolition of the excise duty.

     The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    Before the 1st September of this year the Sugar Industry of Singapore (SIS) was the sole supplier of refined sugar to the domestic market. SIS concluded favourable long term contracts with Australia and Fiji for the supply of raw sugar. In the last 10 years, world sugar prices fluctuated widely but the long term contracts guaranteed us regular supplies of sugar at stable and comparatively low prices.

    This situation has now changed. There is a world sugar glut, as governments in Europe and the United States are subsidizing their sugar growers.
